conclusion: Ion implantation is a crucial step in chip manufacturing, involving velocity selector, magnetic analyzer, and deflection system.
Uniform magnetic fields with magnitude B and electric fields with magnitude E are present in the system.
The magnetic analyzer is a quarter-circular ring with inner and outer radii R1 and R2.
The deflection system is a cube with side length L, parallel to the wafer's horizontal plane.
The system is in a vacuum and gravitational force on ions is negligible.
Small angle approximations: sin(alpha) ≈ tan(alpha) ≈ alpha, cos(alpha) ≈ 1 - 1/2 alpha^2.
Image shows velocity selector, magnetic analyzer, and deflection system with their respective fields.
Ions pass through velocity selector ensuring constant velocity v for specific charge-to-mass ratios.
Magnetic analyzer selects ions with specific charge-to-mass ratio, moving them to point M.
Deflection system has uniform electric and magnetic fields, affecting ion trajectory.
Ions injected vertically at point O are deflected downward to point P by electric field.
Magnetic field causes deflection angle alpha, leading to horizontal displacement from M to Q.
Using small angle approximations, calculate horizontal displacement MQ as Lsin(alpha).
Final position of ions after deflection is determined by combining vertical and horizontal displacements.
